--- sramaswa007@... wrote:
> Hi All,
> 
>   I am designing a project to run junit test cases from the browser.  
> Basically the user is given a form where in he types in the test 
> class he wants to run and clicks the submit button. 
> 
> The test case class is called and the results are returned back to 
> the browser.  I am fine till that part as I am able to call the 
> appropriate test case entered by the user and am able to display the 
> results on the browser.  
> 
> What I also need is that, is there a way to determine and print what 
> test case methods are being run.  As in case of the swingui 
> (junit.swingui.TestRunner) we have the progress bar indicator that 
> tells us how many test cases are run, the failures and errors and the 
> stack trace.  Right now I am able to get all the results but once all 
> the test cases have finished running, till then the page displayed to 
> the user is blank.  Is there anyway to dynamically show which method 
> in the test case is running and whether its a failure or error or 
> success.  Please let me know.
> 
> Thanks,
> Sri

Sri,

Sure this is possible.  But you are limited here by things extraneous to JUnit.
 For instance, the success of the dynamic updating (i.e. the client seeing it
in realtime) is going to depend on the speed of both the webserver and the
browser.  So, you may never really reach a realtime effect in the browser. 
However, I suspect that this will generally be run in a business environment,
so the speeds of the machines should be sufficient enough to _simulate_
realtime.

To dynamically update a page requires that you have a little more magic than
normal going on.  There will of necessity be some software on the client side
that will cause the client's browser to "continuously" reload.  You can feed
pages up to the server until your heart is content, but if the client never
requests them, it does no good.  I am not sure whether you can accomplish this
through an applet, having never used them.  It seems to me that you could write
some script or a servlet to update every 5 seconds or so, or you could just do
this in the HTML (which is not so clean).

All of that being said, is it really necessary to to have this kind of
interface?  What's the motive?  Are the tests running on a server that you want
all clients to be able to see?

-jason
